person.note: The owner of the amulet reports that he found it in a field near Nazereth.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. Although this form is not recorded elsewhere, this is obviously the name intended.
North-east of Damascus.

The suggestion that this is a Jewish inscription is based, 1. On the formula Εἱς Θεός (God is one), but see Introduction 6.1.6; 2. The biblical name Samuel (35) is found in the inscription, but he could be Christian, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52; 3. However, the name of her son, Tanḥum, was clearly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.2.4.
For this form see vol. 3, under Aster G/F, p. 407.
The inscription is accompanied by the Hebrew word שלום (peace), see vol. 3, Introduction 6.2, pp. 33-4.
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.
For this form see vol. 3, under Asteria G/F, p. 407.
See previous note.
The decision to list this person as female is based on the fact that the name was more common for females, but the male ̓Αστερίος is also recorded.
The epitaphs are bilingual – Hebrew and Greek. The Hebrew (BS1:126) has אסתר. So in the Greek (BS2:88). Although this form is not recorded elsewhere, this is obviously the name intended.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
Although this form is not recorded elsewhere, this is obviously the name intended.

note.ref: See above, n. 12. This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

person.note: For this form see vol. 3, under Esther (3) B/F, p. 175.
In Greek – Τυρία (in Lebanon). On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.

note.ref: See above, n. 12. This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

person.note: For this form see vol. 3, under Aster G/F, p. 407.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
The inscription is dated to 380 years after the destruction, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
Though not recorded elsewhere, I assume this is the name intended.
In Greek – προσσυλήτου.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see above, n. 15. For this form see vol. 3, under Esther (3) B/F, p. 175.
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The city of Caesarea included a mixed population of Jews pagans and Christians, see Introduction 6.2.1.2.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
The inscription is dated to 398 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
On the additional י as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. This may be a transliteration of the name back from the Greek into Jewish characters, see Introduction 2.2.
In the Golan, north east of the Sea of Galilee.
In the north-western Negev.
In LXX the name is transliterated Δεββώρα (H & R Suppl. 51). In Josephus Δαβώρα. This is somewhere in the middle, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1 and 2.1.1.1, pp. 17-8.
In Greek – δ.́On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.1, p. 35.
One of the forms in which this name was transliterated into Greek in translations of the Bible, see H & R Suppl. 51.
Located on the northern shore of the Sea of Galilee.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

In LXX the transliteration of this name is ̔Αγάρ. Josephus has ̔Αγάρη, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1 and 2.1.1.1, pp. 17-8. However the suffix here looks like it is a transformation of a Latin genitive case ending, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2.1, p. 18.
Kibbutz south of the Sea of Galilee.

Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. Also, on how exact the name is see above, n. 2. In LXX the transliteration of this name is ̔Αγάρ. Josephus has ̔Αγάρη, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.1.1 and 2.1.1.1, pp. 17-8. However the suffix here looks like it is a transformation of a Latin genitive case ending, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2.1, p. 18.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

So in Syriac, ROC1/9 (1904) 88, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.8.1, pp. 18-9. In Hebrew this would read אנא. Te name seems like a transliteration back into Semiic chatacters from the Greek form of the name see Introduction 2.2.
So in Coptic, ROC1/9 (1904) 320, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read ̓́Αννα.For this form see vol. 3, under Hannah (1) B/F, p. 177.
The text describes her son’s conversion, elevation to the bishophood and subsequent martyrdom at the hands of Julian the apostate. She is also described as accepting his faith.
This is a famous legend.
These are the years of Helena’s visit to Jerusalem, see Introduction 7.1.
On sages in this family being called after their mothers see Ilan, Silencing the Queen, 254-5.
Her son was a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
Although told in BT, the aim of this story is demonstrate the behaviour of the “great ones” of the Land of Israel (תקיפי דארעא דישראל), see Introduction 5.1.3.2.1.
Although mentioned only in BT, she is the wife of a Palestinian rabbi.
Her husband is a contemporary of Rabbi Yonah (2)’s son, see Introduction 7.4.3.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. So in Coptic, ROC1/9 (1904) 320, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read ̓́Αννα.For this form see vol. 3, under Hannah (1) B/F, p. 177.

person.note: My reading. The editor read ̓Ανα[νία]. For this form see vol. 3, under Hannah (3) B/F, p. 177.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. So in Coptic, ROC1/9 (1904) 320, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read ̓́Αννα.For this form see vol. 3, under Hannah (1) B/F, p. 177.

person.note: This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. So in Coptic, ROC1/9 (1904) 320, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 31. In Greek this would read ̓́Αννα.For this form see vol. 3, under Hannah (1) B/F, p. 177.

person.note: In Greek, in Jewish characters – קירא. On this title see Introduction 3.1.3.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 15. This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

person.note: For this form see vol. 1, under Hannah (1) B/F, p. 240.
In Greek – ἐτῶν πεντήκοντα. On these details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated, according to the era of the Province of Arabia, see Introduction 7.5.2.2.
For this form see vol. 3, under Hannah (6) B/F, p. 177.
In Greek – Βισαρηνή.
East of Tel Aviv.

Jewishness suggested based on both names. Usually this would not be enough, but her father’s name, Μαθιθία in this form, rather than Mathias, would be typically Jewish (Introduction 6.2.2) and the provenance of these people (Beit She‘arim) also suggests Jewishness, see Introduction 5.2.2.2).
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
The inscription is dated to 369 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
For this form see vol. 1, under Joanna (6) S-H/F, p. 420.
Although mentioned only in BT, she is associated in this tradition with Rabbi Yohanan (1), and see Introduction 5.1.3.2.3.
She is mentioned in a tradition cited by Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.
The inscription is dated to 286 years after the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
For this form see vol. 1, under Joanna (7) S-H/F, p. 420.
In Greek – τεχνίτη. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3.
The inscription contains the formula Εἵς θεός (one God), but bears no Christian markers, see Introduction 6.1.6.

Jarry translates ̓Ιωανα Μαρκιανη τεχνίτη ἐπηησαν with “Jean et Marcien mâitres d’oeuvre ont fait.” According to him the orthographie is “extrêmement fantaisiste,” interpreting the names as those of two males. However, this is unlikely.
The inscription is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.
The form of this name in LXX is Λεία, see H & R Suppl 101. On the interchange of ει and η see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.2, p. 21.
Jewishness may be suggested based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.2.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
The epitaph is bilingual. So in the Greek. We may be certain this is the name intended here because of the Hebrew parallel.
The epitaph is bilingual. So in the Hebrew. On the replacement of the ה suffix with א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
This is how this name is spelt in LXX, see H & R Suppl. 111.
In Greek – ἔτ(η)ιγ.́ On these see details vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The location of the find suggests this, but see Introduction 6.1.5.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1.
These are Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in them, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
Chronology calculated roughly according to the Tulida, see Introduction 7.2.1.
See above, n. 2. In the Samaritan script, see Introduction 2.5.1. .

note.ref: See above, n. 3. These are Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2.1. All the persons mentioned in them, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
See above, n. 4. Chronology calculated roughly according to the Tulida, see Introduction 7.2.1.

person.note: On this form see vol. 3, under Mariam (12) B/F, p. 180.
See previous note.
Jewishness may be suggested based on names found on the inscription, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.2.
So in BS1:8 in Hebrew. On the additional י as a dialect variant see vol 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13.

So in BS2:9 in Greek. Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see vol. 1, under Mariam (1) B/F, p. 242. On the double consonant μ see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.4, p. 22.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

See above, n. 22. The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

person.note: The inscription is dated to the destruction of the Temple, but is unclear at this point. According to the 7 year cycle that is also documented on the inscription, this could be either 312 or 382, see Introduction 7.5.2.1.
Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On this form see above, n. 8. On this form see vol. 3, under Mariam (12) B/F, p. 180.
In Greek – Βοσστρ[ην]ῆς. On Bostra see Introduction 3.2.1.
Jewishness suggested by Di Segni, based on name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52.
The י here has a vowel function, see vol. 4, Introduction 2.3.5.2, p. 13. The fall of the ה is inexplicable..
She is mentioned in association with Eleazar (8), see Introduction 7.4.3.
Stenhouse claims that she is also mentioned in Abu’l Fath, 161, but I was not able to read her name in the Arabic.
This is a Samaritan chronicle, see Introduction 5.1.2. All the persons mentioned in it, unless otherwise stated, are Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.2.
These are the dates of Baba Rabba (Bebai [1]). She is his contemporary, see Introdution 7.2.3.
For this form see vol. 3, under Rebecca (1) B/F, p. 185.
North of Jericho.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
Reading reconstructed by the editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1. For this form see vol. 3, under Rebecca (6) B/F, p. 185.
This is a Samaritan synagogue, see Introduction 6.1.4.
In LXX her name is recorded as ̔Ρούθ, see H & R Suppl. 131. The additional ε may be a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.1, p. 20.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.

This is an unusual form but the intention is clear. Either the χ has fallen (as in vol. 1, under Rachel (1), B/F, p. 248), as a result of a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20, or this is a nother dialect, indicating the decline of the laryngeals, see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.1, p. 28.
In Greek – ̓Ασιθα. Probably biblical Ezion-Geber, according to the editors. On this sort of designation see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
On the form סמבטי see vol. 3, Under Shabtai (113) B/M, p. 152. This is the Greek form of this name, transliterated back into Hebrew, see Introduction 2.2.

In Hebrew – [אר]כונית, [אר]בעים שנ[ה]. On this title as the feminine for archon, and its implications see D. Stoekel Ben Ezra, “A Jewish Archontess: Remarks on an Epitaph from Byblos,” ZPE 169 (2009) 287-93. On the age details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
In Lebanon.
The inscription is in Hebrew characters, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.2, pp. 33-4.
According to IJO 3, Syr30 the inscription is dated to the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.
Although it is very remote from the original, I assume this is the name intended.

She is described in this text as choosing to convert to Christianity (ibid.,100) which suggests that to begin with she was not Christian. With such a name (translated in the text to Greek as Εἰρήνη – peace, ibid., 98) living in Gaza in Palestine, she was initially probably Jewish.
The calculation was made by the editor of this document.
For this form see vol. 1, under Salome (1) B/F, p. 249. On the interchange of ω and ο see vol. 1, Introduction 2.3.3.1, p. 22.
The inscription is accompanied by the Hebrew word שלום (peace), see vol. 3, Introduction 6.2, pp. 33-4.

Jewishness indicated by name, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
This is an unusual transliteration of this name, but see Σαλαμάθ in vol. 1, under Salome (10), B/F, p. 249. On this feminine suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.4.1, pp. 27-8.
This is the year in which Beth She‘arim was destroyed, see Introduction 7.5.1.
In Lebanon.

person.note: She is a contemporary of Rabbi Abbahu (1), who is a contemporary of Rabbi Yohanan (1), see Introduction 7.4.1.

div.note: Biblical, Exod 6:23. אלישבע was Aaron’s wife.
Biblical, e.g. Esth 2:7. אסתר was the queen who gave her name to the biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 4:4. דבורה was an important prophetess and judge.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:21. דינה was Jacob’s daughter.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 16:1. הגר was Abraham’s concubine.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:2. חנה was the prophet Samuel’s mother.
יוחנה is the feminine form of the biblical יוחנן. It is, however, never mentioned in the Bible. For female names derived from male names see vol. 3, Introduction 1.1.2.1, p. 6.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:16. לאה was Jacob’s first wife.

מיכאלה is the feminine form of the biblical מיכאל (e.g. Num 13:13). It is, however, never mentioned in the Bible, and thus not counted as biblical. For female names derived from male names see vol. 3, Introduction 1.1.2.1, p. 6.
Biblical, e.g. Num 26:33.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 15:20. מרים was Moses’ sister.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 2:22. Sipora was Moses’ wife.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 22:23. רבקה was Isaac’s wife.
Biblical, e.g. Ruth 1:4. רות is the Moabite woman who gave the book the name.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:6. רחל was Jacob’s beloved wife.

שבתית is the feminine form of the biblical שבתאי (e.g. Ezra 10:15). It is, however, never mentioned in the Bible. It was probably invented in post-biblical times, see vol. 3, Introduction 1.1.2.1, p. 6.
In the Bible שלום is recorded only as a man’s name (one of the last kings of Israel, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:10).
Biblical, Exod 1:15. שפרה was a Jewish midwife at the time of the Exodus.
Biblical, e.g. Gen. 17:15. שרה was Abraham’s wife.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 38:6. תמר was Judah’s daughter-in-law and mother of his children.
